element_texts.text:
1
On the Negroes and Slavery of the Peons in Mexico.

When Mexico separated from Old Spain, her military rulers declared the negroes free. The Spaniards being the principal possessors of slaves had to give them up without any compensation.  Declaring the negro free gave the Mexicans in the eyes of the United States & England a humane character, and contributed in a great measure to her recognition.

Some of the liberated negroes were dragged in chains to the army, whilst others left their old masters & their homes, wandering about in idleness, until forced by starvation to apply for work.

 The negroes now became hired servants, their masters getting them into debt - and now they were really slaves again.  If the Negro wished to charge his master, the new Master had to

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, big-endian, direntries=9], baseline, precision 8, 1603x1973, frames 3

element_texts.text:
2
pay his debts & after the free negro, found an account against him of 3 to 400 dollars. If he had the temerity to discuss the first point, the prison for debt stared him in the face, & he was then forced to go again into a servitude little better than slavery to a new master.

 Now comes another species of slavery, & shows that todo Mexicano no es libre - all Mexicans are not free - but the different Constituciones say they are.
 Reverting to the times of the old Spaniards, & bringing them up to those of the Republica, it will be seen that the majority of Mejicanos libres, are really as much slaves as the negroes of Louisiana.
 The Conquerors of Mexico had large tracts of land alloted to them, or they took any quantity they required calling it an Encomienda, and all the indians upon it, became slaves.
Hard

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, big-endian, direntries=9], baseline, precision 8, 1541x1939, frames 3

element_texts.text:
3
labour particularly that of Mining reduced by premature death the greater number of captives or slaves.

 Negroes were now introduced, as these were purchased, they were legally the property of the buyer.
 After a time a new race sprang up - viz - the Mexican, being a mixture of Indian, Negro & Spaniard, & this race has ultimately become the Masters of a great Empire, aided by disloyalty of Spanish troops!
 Now then the more revolutionary of the Mexicans! having become possessors of the property of the old Spaniards, became also masters of the peons or laborers & their families & who are just in the same position as the free negro already described.  x
 There are several estates in Mexico have many thousands of these peon slaves upon them. Santana himself has estates worked by this class of people.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, big-endian, direntries=9], baseline, precision 8, 1585x1976, frames 3

element_texts.text:
4
As nearly the greater part of the population of Mexico are of the peon class, so the greater part are slaves - and yet these Mejicanos libres know not how to villify enough, a few planters and farmers, who after being invited to settle the then wilderness of Texas with their slaves - men who would not suffer a Military despotism & who by the force of [?]  times are obliged to have recourse to slave labour. But this handful of farmers taught Mexico a severe lesson  on the field of San Jacinto & when their President the Sanguinary Santa Anna sued for his life - & he obtained it, & how has he kept his promise to Texas?

 But to return to the negroes in Texas, he is as well clad, better fed & though he bears the name of slave, if he be not a "bad nigger" he will pass his life easily. Negroes occasionally leave their Texan masters & go to Mexico, in a short time they

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, big-endian, direntries=9], baseline, precision 8, 1361x1717, frames 3

element_texts.text:
x
Each Saturday the peon receives his weekly allowance of Indian corn, about a peck. And at San Luis de Potose (1842) three dollars only per month was their pay; this way even  more was expended at the tienda or store upon the estate, thus keeping the peon continually in debt.  The peon is allowed one day in each month to himself, when if they are not much in debt & wish to change, they look out for a new master, but this day is deducted from their months pay.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, big-endian, direntries=9], baseline, precision 8, 1336x1712, frames 3

element_texts.text:
Maguey  -  (Agave Americana)  It is this plant that furnishes the Pulque, but ere it is fermented the liquor that exudes from it is called "Agua de Miel" - I am informed that some 20 or more sorts of eatables & drinkables are prepared from this, to use a Texan phrase "Great Plant"  

  It is the Mezcal, another species of Agave that yields a liquor of same name - to obtain this drink, the root is pounded, mixed with water and fermented, from which is obtained an intoxicating drink - other parts of this plant is used & by the Indians & even the missions - In the Guadalupe Mts at the foot of which we arrived, or rather into them, saw small specimens of these plants, but on the other side of the Nueces say, above the Pasido Rd they commence & then continue thro' Mexico - Should a failure of Maquey crop happen, it would be a serious affair for domestic trade - (see into this)  I do not think "Chicha" as made by the Peruvians & Chilians from "Indian Corn" is used by the Mexicans.

Sunday afternoon light rain & cloudy - [?Yacht?] Dolphin Capt Houston Anchored [?] N. Orleans - during the week fine weather and mild - Winds from E - N.E. -
Tuesday 20th  Sailed down to 'Dolphin' [?] Capt H & Capt Eller going on Shore.  Capt E introduced me to Capt  H - received me very formally - asked him if he had any letters for me from W. K Pringle - "Had none"  This ended our acquaintance.
Wenesday 21.  Very fine weather light [?] N. airs - &  warm enough to find a few Mosquitos in the low lands -

 Mr. St. John brought the letter from Kennedy by 'Alpha' 95 days from London

element_texts.text:
X 
Arranged Col. Cooke, Howard Robson & others to see the Missions
See Law of Congress Jany 13. 1841.  Cession of the Mission Church - Lots  &c - to the Roman Catholic Congregations - St Anto, the Alamo Church (Jany 18th 1841), Goliad & Victoria, Church lot at Nacogdoches, churches at Concepcion, St. Jose, San Juan, Espada & Mission of Refugio -
X  This Mission had 11 Leagues given to it for pasture land, this side of the Medina - Commencing at Loma del Paderon 12 miles from St Anto & running westerly 7 or 8 miles W of the Medina  - It was then purchased by Refugio dela Garza & the curate of St Anto from - the Indians & their descendants who had under? their men the foundation  Garza sold it to MacMullen - it was then located by Speculators, & is now in litigtn?.

element_texts.text:
Col. Cooke who was principal Commissioner tells me that - he ordered that Waggons should not be sent - in case of a difficulty. Gl. Lamar hoped during his Administration that with the few that he ultimately permitted to go, could have been able to have revolutionized Santa Fe in favor of Texas & then had a direct trade - Poes jucio haber en asto - And as Texas claims the Rio Grande as its boundary, he fondly hoped to have had it soon enrolled as a Texan Ag?

 But their would have been difficulty with the U.S. Traders, for had it succeeded, it must have curlacted? their trade - But a much better trade awaits the Texans - Viz the Rio Grande & onwards to Chihuahua.

element_texts.text: X  On the Arroyo of Sn Pedro 1/2 mile dist  but depredations of the Comanches, forced them to settle the spot now known as Sn Anto, between the Arrroys  Sn Pedro & the San Anto River and put under the Guardianship of San Antonio de Austria & sometimes called the 'Asiento'.  Harms & McMul break? about same time.

element_texts.text:
Tuesday 3rd - Our party enjoyed themselves much on the Sascusty? last night  the glass went round, the song was sung, but not one from the Americans of the party - they are very fond of convivial parties, but odd truth, more than tippetey & smoking -  ?? raisy but obland a skiled?? of the mission.

 The Alamo was a Mission, a Military Post, and Presidio when convicts were sent to & settled up by Emigrants from the Canary islands San Anto founded in 1715 who spoke Spanish & were first located on the X
  Weather has come in rainy and cloudy - making roads heavy. And it would appear that such changeable weather is hardly in the recollection of the oldest inhabitant.

In proof of this even when Woll came in with the following Autumn, there was no pillaging, and had not the citizens been taken with in Arms, He would not in all probability made them prisoners - i.e.? the Perta? prisoners - His object was to prevent the West from becoming settled, to whmmdat? the foreign residents & scare if possible the Americans - & if there was a chance of getting to, the then almost depopulated Austin, which was then the n..nd? Capital of the Republic & were the Archives? were, rather to have destroyed those Records, or have taken them to Mexico - 1 to have trumpeteted? for Victory.  It is only 3 days march with an army to Austin - but his orders were to go beyond Sn Anto -  2  I think the

element_texts.text: Colorado River was high, & ma be could have done much damage to the defenseless Capital  the trust? all around would have poured forth its hundreds of rifle balls - and every one would have told?.  Indeed I know that Woll was censured by Santana for going with to the Salado, posting himself when he did even with 1100 Men, & when a handful of Texans in the narrow bottom whipped him.  Probably two things combined - to save him from disgrace - 1  The Entry of the Texas Citizens into Mexico as  prisoners & 2  the slaughter of Dawsons Company - & the (part..l?)]], picking? up of the West - but as a ? off he had 150 Killed & Wounded.

Mission of San Jose more than 1200 deaths are noted down - this would prove that as ? of Christianity & civilization such as the Missionaries gave them, did not tend to enable their numbers, & the Wild life they sghed? after, they canto? not get, thus reduced them - & it appears that no particular obsiate? or excess thus anhilated them - After the indians were then got rid of, Many Mexicans came in & commenced working the lands opened by the Native indians.   Part of the produce of the land and catch, went to supply the garission at the Alamo, the Missionaries being paid for the same.

element_texts.text:
5 PM Heavy Thunder storm & Rains - The Town, and Roads a perfect quagmire. From Sun down to 10 PM 'A Considerable up-start ?att? rain"

Wednesday 4th - Rain all night. Mg cloudy - Last night stopped at Mr Lagino, heard Mr Chevalier give an account of his hair bedth  ?? after being taken prisoner, (when out spying with Mr Dunn) by Mexican 'scouts' who preceded Vasquez - He disonbed? his break from S. Anjo from the Mexicans when on his parole, know key? one of the soldiers down - &c - making for the head of the River, the guard after him - getting up into a tree, whilst then Mexicans and indians (Cherokees) for three days upon his trail, & often under his hiding place - At one turn he heard voices speaking English, ?

element_texts.text: he thought he might descend, but on looking before he leaped, he saw it was, a Mexican ?all? a lot of Northern indians who spoke English, on the look out after him - Had to  play possum again. After a ?all? amt time had elapsed, he descended got into the bed of the River  waded up it some distance, got out upon some Rocks, so that his tract might not be traced & will as Blanked only, made his way E. toward the Salado, & soon met some of his friends venturing to San Anjo -

element_texts.text:
Part III
San Antonio de Bejar  Octr. 1. 1843
Sunday 1st.  We have now fine weather the N.E. Winds & Rains appear to have lift (Equanastral)? and balmy indeed is the air; the few clouds floating about, prevent the sun's rays from being oppressive. Son & self passed a good night - took 3q ? more of Quinine -

 The Evenings are pleasant & still, save near the river and Eseguinas (aqueducts for irrigating the land) when a very few Mosquitos, but they meet with their now failing enemy the Mosquito Hawk; but about 1 AM. one is often awakened by the Roosters (Cocks) in the vicinity,  One must not say Cock at them diggings? when one has for half an hour
